posts.sub: Welcome to /his/ - History & Humanities
posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14641716
Labor unions: Marx and Engels saw the need for workers to band together in labor unions to demand better working conditions and wages. Unions have since played a key role in securing many of the rights and protections that workers enjoy today, including the right to collective bargaining, the 8-hour workday, and workplace safety regulations.

Social safety nets: Marxist ideas about the need for a "social safety net" to protect workers from the risks and uncertainties of the capitalist economy have been influential in the development of modern social welfare programs. Programs like unemployment insurance, workers' compensation, and disability benefits are all examples of social safety net programs that help protect workers from the worst effects of economic instability.

Workplace safety regulations: Marx and Engels argued that capitalists had a vested interest in exploiting workers and cutting corners on safety, and therefore workers needed to demand safety regulations to protect themselves. Today, workplace safety regulations, such as OSHA in the United States, have saved countless lives and prevented countless injuries.

The minimum wage: Marx and Engels believed that workers should be paid a fair wage that would allow them to live with dignity. The concept of a minimum wage, which sets a floor on the wages that employers can pay, has its roots in Marxist ideas about the exploitation of workers and the need for a living wage.

posts.sub: Most of what people are told about Japanese internment camps is fake.
posts.com:
>As a war-time measure, the federal government required all Japanese-Americans to evacuate a large part of the American Pacific coast. They were free to move from the exclusion zone on their own, and to resettle anywhere else in the United States. Those who did not were taken first to assembly centers and then to ten relocation centers built for them as far east as Arkansas. They could stay in the centers if they wished or they could take jobs or attend college anywhere in the United States except the West Coast.

>The centers were therefore not internment camps, but living facilities offered by the government to those who were forbidden to live in the exclusion area and who did not make other arrangements. The centers, though built in the same austere style as American Army barracks, had many amenities and were run by Japanese-Americans. By the end of 1944, with eight months of war still to go, several thousand people had already left the camps to find homes and jobs in the central and eastern United States. The US Army was careful to look after the evacuees’ property, and Congress appropriated several million dollars soon after the war to compensate Japanese-Americans for losses that did occur.

https://www.amren.com/news/2022/03/the-truth-about-the-japanese-in-america-during-world-war-two/

>>14641567
I've been reading some memoirs of Eastern European peasants (Poland mostly) who grew up under serfdom in the early 19th century and they all talk about it being normal for men to first marry in their early thirties and women in their mid twenties. Younger men would be helping out on their father's farm, and when they got older they'd be finding extra work, mostly in road and river transport, to earn some cash for starting out on their own. Then sometime in their early 30s their relatives would arrange a wife for them. Women would work for their parents until their mid-20s "working off their dowry".

The main exception to this was if a father died early and the eldest son would take over the farm, then you'd have men marrying earlier (as early as their late teens), but they'd likely be marrying a girl in her 20s anyway. All arranged by relatives of course; finding a wife yourself was an unusual thing old men like widowers would do.

Welcome home, anon! May the most high, most just, and most adorable will of God be in all things done, praised, and magnified forever. Amen.

I received Confirmation on Pentecost in '20 during the lockdowns. I remember that zeal and anticipation for my first Communion well. Keep it in your heart and mind! Communion daily is great, I would also suggest a weekly Holy Hour of Adoration if you can manage it. I use this book and have experienced such immense nourishment through this devotion to Our Lord:

https://archive.org/details/VisitsToJesusInTheTabernacle

Other books that have helped me immensely so far are:

"Confessions" by St. Augustine
"Summa Theologiae" by St. Thomas Aquinas
"Lignum Vitae" and "The Soul's Journey into God" by St. Bonaventura
"The Sinners Guide" by Luis de Granada
"The Council of Trent"
"Revolution and Counter-Revolution" by Plinio Correa de Oliveira (really all works by him)
All of Fr. Ripperger's Conferences

Tradition in Action is also a great site for practical ways of amending ones' life in accordance with Catholic moral teaching. Another is New Advent which has all of the Church documents, as well as the Catholic Encyclopedia. I particularly like reading Pope St. Gregory the Great's Epistles there, but they have almost all the documents of the Church Fathers and Doctors of the Church.

Yes, it did for a while, but we need to put this in perspective.

The majority of Americans in the 1960s and 1970s were pretty socially conservative, including the boomers. The hippies and the counter-culture are overrepresented in historiography because they attracted a lot of attention and were wealthy and well educated. Nixon was telling the truth when he spoke of a Silent Majority, who with Reagan ceased to be Silent, and became the Moral Majority.

There was some rightward shift on certain social issues, for instance, support for capital punishment and toughness on crime goes up with the sharp rise in crime throughout the 1970s. But this isn't the case with abortion, that has actually stayed fairly consistent.

The Reagan years represented a time where social conservatives were both the majority and were loud. Therefore, it gives the appearance of the 1980s being a conservative decade.

However, Reagan and the conservative movement he represented did nothing to stop the degeneration of culture, as many have stated, he was more concerned with foreign policy and economics than he was culture. Reagan was a proto-Neocon essentially.

I would have loved to have lived in 1980s and 1990s America, it seems like the perfect 'goldilocks zone' where genuine racism was bad but we didn't have woke. However, the Reagan Revolution was always going to lead to where we are today. Reagan did not stop the rot in the universities. If he'd done what DeSantis is doing now in Florida nationwide, there was still a chance in the 80s that it could have been defeated, but social conservatives were arrogant in assuming that they would always be the majority, and got complacent.

The problem with the conservative movement is that it needs the support of big capital. Intellectuals and trade unions have a culture of opposing social conservatism, so if social conservatives want to get anywhere, they need to be benefactors of big business.

I hate the way money in politics works in the US, and envision a system where there are major restrictions on it, but in order to get that new system you need to win at the current system first, and you need to have the support of 'an' elite, whoever they are.

The alternative to an embrace of neoliberalism would probably have been a clientelistic system, where funders of conservative causes get favoured by the government.

Yes, this is corrupt, but it's corruption that serves a purpose. It's how Viktor Orban is able to maintain establishment support for his agenda in Hungary. >>14637709
>They would have made more political progress without the terror and civilian attacks
The IRA did not start the Troubles.

Northern Ireland in the 1960s (and lesser extend 1950s) had its own Civil Rights movement which *was* a peaceful attempt to reform Northern Ireland. They wanted equality in housing, equality in voting, and an end to the draconian Unionist discrimination against Catholics in general. The Government of NI at the time, lead by Terence O'Neill, appeared open to the prospect of gradual peaceful reform-and the Taoiseach of the Republic, Seán Lemass, wanted good north-south relations.

Hardline Ulster Unionists formed paramilitaries in the mid 1960s and began attacking Civil Rights demonstrations, as they were opposed to any change in Nationalism's favour, and were also opposed to any cooperation with the south. They started shooting/bombing people around 1966, and throughout the late 1960s also set off bombs in the Republic of Ireland. Some of these they blamed on the IRA, which was inactive at the time and had been since their failed border campaign years prior.

The Unionist paramilitary violence caused riots in Irish Nationalist areas, and when the local police (RUC) sided with the Unionist paramilitaries, riots became more intense. In 1969 the British Army was called in to deal with the situation, but they too were seen as being too friendly with the paramilitaries and the police. Shortly after *that* the IRA got involved.
Again, the IRA didn't kill as many civilians as the British side did.

> An overwhelming majority of Ireland voted in favour of an independent democratic Republic.
And an overwhelming majority of Northern Ireland voted against it. What's good for the goose is good for the gander. You can't declare independence from a country you've been an integral part of for centuries and then turn around to your own breakaway region and say 'no, you can't declare independence from *us*, our territorial integrity is inviolable'.

>which almost immediately descended into a corrupt, sectarian shitshow.
As if the Republic was any less corrupt or sectarian. The only reason it didn't have the same sectarian problems as the north is that they eradicated their Protestant population very early on - many were driven out by targeted attacks during the War of Independence, Civil War, and immediate aftermath, and most of the rest left in the '20s and '30s as discrimination in jobs and government services made it impossible to exist (i.e. basically the same things Catholics would later complain about in the north, ironically). The only Protestants who remained in the South were some upper class Protestants in Dublin, whose businesses and expertise the Republic couldn't afford to do without, and a handful of small communities that were just large enough to get by on their own resources, and out of the way enough not to attract attention.

If North and South had been united, there would still have been a long-running sectarian civil war, the sides would just have been reversed.

And let's not forget that the Republic was an economic catastrophe up to the 1990s, and politically dominated by the Catholic church. If I asked you whether you'd like to return to the conditions the Republic had pre-1990s I'm betting you'd be vehemently against it, and then you turn around and pretend you don't know exactly why Ulster didn't want to be a part of that and blame it on "British intervention".

>>14637916
>The IRA did not start the Troubles.
>Northern Ireland in the 1960s (and lesser extend 1950s) had its own Civil Rights movement which *was* a peaceful attempt to reform Northern Ireland.
This is the central lie at the heart of every misunderstanding about the Troubles. The simple version of the story told to most people is that Northern Ireland split from the rest of the island during the War of Independence, and then nothing much happened for forty years until the Troubles started.

This is completely wrong. Although the South officially gave up attempts to recover the North, the IRA continued armed campaigns - not terrorist campaigns, but full-on invasions. The cross-border guerrilla attacks continued through WW2 (when the IRA tried to take advantage of the UK being distracted by WW2, and also tried to ally with the Nazis), into the early '50s. These had the tacit support of much of the Republic's government, although this was intermittent and waxed and waned according to how worried they were about British retaliation.

By the late '50s it was clear that these weren't working. Then in the early '60s the peaceful civil rights movement got started, and wouldn't you know it, a lot of the former IRA were to be found among the ranks of the peaceful protesters. Now, you can argue forever how sincere their conversion to pacifism was, but either way any reasonable person should be able to see how to the Protestants of Northern Ireland, the Civil Rights movement *looked* like just a front for a different version of the IRA.

The peaceful Civil Rights movement lasted for all of five minutes once the prod paramilitary groups started their attacks. 'We tried peaceful protests and it didn't work, oh well, back to violence.'

>>14641645
Anarchism was more of a thing in countries with, how do I say this, uneven capitalist development in which you still had peasants or basically recent peasants nostalgic for the communal living experience. The reds often saw anarchism as having a reactionary streak running through it, nevertheless the anarchists saw their enemies as kings, crowns and capitalists. And there were various middle-class adventurers in the mix too. It's also worth noting they literally did go around assassinating those enemies and throwing dynamite into orchestra pits at the opera and were treated as a major security threat by governments at the time.

Pancho Villa's men didn't describe themselves as anarchists, but I think guys like that were part of the same phenomenon at the same time. Mexico was different than Spain, Italy or Ukraine but these guys had basically been like serfs in debt bondage working on haciendas. Another anon pointed out the Zapatistas in Mexico who draw on that legacy, they're like libertarian socialists / anarchists basically but I don't think the specific ones in Chiapas get caught up on labels or definitions. The anarchists were also major competitors to what would later be called Marxism during the 19th century, but the latter became the main left-wing force after the October Revolution, although you see anarchists sticking around, again, in countries like Spain which were pretty underdeveloped.

I'd add that there are anarchists in the world who do still mean business. The North American left is its own mutant thing, both the anarchists and the socialists in the U.S. has a unique, I dunno, character that is distinct from their counterparts in the rest of the world, which is a whole other discussion.

But to answer your question though (!), it's my opinion at least that a lot of North American anarchism is popular on the left, to the extent that The Conquest of Bread returns significantly higher search results from North America than State and Revolution, is because it's similar to liberalism, which is a significantly stronger political tradition in the U.S. than most countries, it's practically in the air that Americans breath. Even the U.S. conception of republicanism is distinct from the French concept of the "general will" and "common good" and so on; you can see how that birthed socialism. Russians endlessly debated the French Revolution, which was the tradition they drew from, when they made their own revolution, as they lacked a pre-existing democratic tradition.

But if you take the American concept of freedom for example, that means freedom from domination by political authority (the state); this theory is strictly a vertical one. That's how libertarians take it (freedom to own property with as little state interference as possible). On the left, it turns into something like communism, but discarding respect for private property, and including employers as a dominating group who we're trying to free ourselves from, but nobody can tell you what to do either (like doing drugs, etc., although it's fun to ask them if they support the Zapatistas shooting drug traffickers if you want to troll).

Employers in this framework are bad because of the hierarchical relationship. In Marxist socialism, employers are bad because employees are unfree as a *status*, you can be arbitrarily fired by your boss, and this unfree relationship exists even if the boss doesn't act on it, because he could, at any moment. That comes out of republicanism, not liberalism, but both have interacted in U.S. history, liberalism is quite strong though.

posts.sub: Incan Empire thread
posts.com:
there is no empire throughout history that brings as much wonder and curiosity as them, they were essentially snuffed out in their cradle. Pachacuti's empire only lasted a hundred years from his ascension to the Spanish conquest.
Now Pachacuti was a unique type of leader and i do believe most of it although wrapped in symbolism. but more importantly than the story is what he built. He is far more civil engineer than conqueror his government was first and foremost a way to organize labor and resources in order to construct and maintain the many Roads and Andenes throughout the empire, as well as prevent famine and generally improve the living conditions.
This is marked by the fact that the Incas always needed to expand their arable land because each Andean Peasant was ascribed an allotment of land to feed themselves and their village with. in return they would participate in a Corvee for 3 months of the year which they would perform services for the state such as, constructing Andenes, Roads, and participating in the other monumental projects that the empire undertook.
Andenes were raised beds for agriculture built into the sides of mountains and are usually irrigated. they were primarily used to manipulate the soil temperatures to be suitable for three sisters agriculture and plenty of potatoes. these andenes cover about 2.5 million hectares of the former Incan empire but have fallen out of use because you cant use a tractor on them.
The Inca new something many other civilizations have failed to learn. that people can create vast surplus in a inhospitable environment through collective planning and hard work. much akin to the Dutch in the Netherlands but instead of reclaiming land from the sea the Andeans carved it from a dry slab of rock. I really think if they survived they could have became something incredibly special and it's such a tragedy that the Spanish tried to destroy these peoples so thoroughly.

posts.com:
>>14629501
there are resources about them, they just typically aren't called "Inca" because the Inca had what was essentially institutionalized ethnicities. The Inca themselves referred to the ethnic group from the kingdom of cusco, which ruled over the empire of many other conquered kingdoms and smaller ayllus, which were small clans that belonged to a few villages (which could be spread across vast distances)

so if you want to learn about typical village life in the inca empire, it's going to be different as per the culture - on a universal level, they all were subject to the mit'a and mitma, as well as other forms of taxation, and were offered land and resources like alpacas as well as access to the qapaq nan, and protection. on a more individual level you will have to look at specific cultures - different aymaran cultures, or people like the chancay, chanka, chimor, chachapoyas... there are resources on these peoples but its a bit harder to find.

The Incas basically required that you wear the clothes of your ethnicity and practice your culture - this extended to state systems like the army or corvee labor - you worked with people from your culture

>>14630856
A very recent study on how this appeared in relation to clothing specifically: https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0280511

"Standardization, such as that found in the unku, is likely related to the need of the state to reproduce its symbols of power. Therefore, garments had to adhere as strictly as possible to the standard parameters that gave these pieces an eminently imperial character; however, it has also been pointed out that one of the political strategies of the Inka state was to coordinate the diversity of the peoples, with their different cultures, languages, and traditions, without trying to homogenize them completely. The Inka promoted diversity and allowed local groups to produce material culture and conduct local ritual behavior in ways that represented their ethnic identity [14, 42]. In short, the relationship between the state and local communities was a dialectical process that varied from region to region and village to village, depending on the pressure exerted by the state and the receptivity of local groups [40, 43]. In our opinion, these historical contexts would have generated the conditions for local weavers to introduce morphological, technological, and stylistic features with low visibility, attributes which did not radically transform the imperial character of these iconic objects that represented the state."

there's still a level of assimilation involved - the state did have a lot of control over its subjects, especially compared to another empire like the aztecs for example. but they certainly organized the imperial structure around ethnicity. Entire cultures were treated depending on how loyal they were as subjects, or in the short term if they fought against conquest or simply accepted it. loyal ayllus were sent to the frontiers of the empire to develop it while the less loyal were brought close to cuzco to be more easily controlled

>>14634582
Kind of like >>14634594 said, the Argument from Motion could at best be an argument for Deism. God had one line in history's script, that was "let there be light" and then he got the fuck out of the way. Might even be true for all I know, we don't have any better ideas so far for why matter and consciousness exist.

But I don't want to give Aquinas that much credit. That whole argument is based on a really common fallacy--where you build up a useful and descriptive metaphor or lens for describing real-world events, and then try to treat that metaphor as a solid fact on which you can prove a point.

Communists do the same thing all the time. There's nothing wrong with describing a society in terms of the "means of production", "mode of production" "bourgeoisie", "proletariat", etc. You can look at any society and identify those things, and sometimes that's actually a useful way to analyze them. But once you've accepted that "means of production" and the "proletariat" are a thing, communists will assert that it is absolute proof that the right or correct future for society is that the proletariat seize the means of production, and they seem to have an airtight rationale for doing so.

But that argument is all based on nothing more than a useful metaphor. "Means of production" aren't a real or universal or true thing. They're an artificial category we slap over things to help make sense of them in a certain light. Useful as far as it goes, but no basis for proving any kind of supposed universal or objective truth.

"potentials" and "actuals" are no more valid of a basis for proving anything than "means of production" or the "proletariat".

It sounds really deep and wise and philosophical at first blush, but there is no substance to it.

Aquinas is sneaking in an assertion as he frames his question, and it's that assertion that needs to be challenged:

>Aquinas is not arguing for a beginning to the universe, but rather for a causal power that is operating right now.

That's assuming you already agree with half his premise--that there is a difference between the chain of cause and effect through time since the beginning of the universe (if it even had a beginning--I also dispute the assertion that it might not be infinite through time as well as space), and the chain of cause and effect that causes things to be "actualized" within any given moment.

That whole assertion is made up and I'm not sure what his basis is for it. The causes for what things are and where they are, how they behave and how they move, in any given moment, are in the previous moment. The chain of cause and effect is entirely material, and it is absolute. If you could hypothetically know about the nature of, and forces acting upon, every single particle of matter following the Big Bang, you'd have a perfect and complete roadmap of the way the universe would progress in the future, down to what you ate for breakfast this morning. "motion" is real, sure, but things will only move in one way. Unless the multiversefags are right, things have only happened one way, and only will happen one way, regarding every single thing in the universe, from stars and supernovas to ants and dust mites.

>inb4 yeah but what's before the Big Bang
Don't know. But even though it sounds counterintuitive--there's no reason this chain of material causality could not be infinite.

Also actually I just thought of something. The problem of induction says that inductive knowledge is fallible - just because every swan you've seen is white, doesn't mean that all swans are necessarily white. There might be black swans that we just haven't seen before (then we found them, in Australia). In fact maybe unicorns exist, and we've just not found them yet. On Mars or something. Can't necessarily rule it out.

So when Christians say "there must have been a first cause, an unmoved mover, because EVERYTHING has a cause" - isn't that fallible inductive reasoning? Everything you've seen might have had a cause, but does that necessarily mean that EVERYTHING must have a cause? Surely that's inductive. So surely it's fallible. And it might be the case that not everything has a cause (so maybe the universe is uncaused).

It is not we who call ourselves Lutherans. Rather, our adversaries call us that. We allow this to the extent that this title is an indication of the consensus that our churches have with the orthodox and catholic doctrine that Luther set forth from Holy Writ. Therefore we allow ourselves to be named after Luther, not as the inventor of a new faith but as the asserter of the old faith and the cleanser of the church from the stains of Papist dogmas. Consequently, we also do not reject the names “Christian” and “catholic,” nor do we render ourselves unworthy of them by the approval of any heretical dogma, as did the Arians, Nestorians, Eutychians, etc. Rather, we are called “Christians” from Christ as the only Author and Teacher of our faith. We are called “catholics” from our consensus with the catholic faith. We are called “Lutherans” from Luther as the asserter and defender of that faith, but especially as the reformer whom God raised up.

+ Johann Gerhard, On the Church (Theological Commonplace XXV)

posts.sub: Spirit of a horse in war, often a neglected point
posts.com:
Medievalists seem to get the horse breeds right. I can find many medieval historians point out that only a certain type of horse like a destrier would be preferred for a heavy knight charge. Riding knee to knee, the horse not only has the bravery to charge in the direction of spears, pikes, and missile fire, but it's got balls big enough to trust the rider to charge directly into them. In some cases they would run over men, kick, bite, and completely jump into the air to create space (only some horses can do this). They had absolutely ridiculous strength to get an armored man in and out of the melee alive. I don't care how well trained a horse is, it's not natural for most breeds to run into and over people or even run directly into a tight formation of enemy horses charging toward them.
However, I never see the spirit of the horse talked about in 20th century when they were most widely used in war. The horse requirements don't seem to mention a distinction in horses being able to fight in a melee. In this age, you needed horses that would not shy from gunfire, yes, but I cannot seem to find mention of a distinction between the horse of a cuirassier and a dragoon. A horse that goes into melee with lance or sabre deliberately rather than skirmishes in hit and run tactics with firearms has to have a distinction, does it not?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14640835
>albanians and bosnians
Neither of these were entirely Islamized, and their Islamization in the areas which did convert, was largely owed to protection and status rather than sincere conversion. Both Albania and Bosnia were the crossroads of Catholicism and Orthodoxy, and the intermediate zones switchted to Islam when it became suitable for them. Take the example of Skanderbeg and his domain, originally Orthodox when under Byzantine or Orthodox Albanian protection, then Islamic when the Ottomans conquered it, and then Catholic after the Battle of Nis and supported by Catholics to revolt.
>>14640785
>How did Georgians and Armenians avoid islamization
Strong literary traditions and earlier conversion to Christianity, ergo a stronger connection. Those in the North Caucasus took longer to convert, and the Circassians for example only became primarily Muslim when Russia was bearing down on them, with Islam becoming means of protection from the Ottomans and defiance to the Russians. Similiarly, while some Chechens had converted to Orthodoxy, a majority were still pagan, and while Islam had been introduced in the 1500s, they didn't become primarily Muslim until the 1800s for the same reason as the Circassians.
Georgia on the other hand was thoroughly Orthodox aside from the brief period of the small Emirate of Tbilisi, which was reconquered, and reconverted to Orthodoxy, by then native to the Georgians. Similiarly, Armenians had been the first nation to convert to Christianity, and were amongst the leading Oriental Orthodox. That said, those under Byzantine rule often became Eastern Orthodox, becoming the Hayhurum, and those later under Islamic rule, did the same and became the Hemshin. Most converts did so for the same reason as those in Albania and Bosnia, status, and protection, their allegiances were fickle in comparison. To this day, there's even still a great Crypto-Christian community in Turkey.

Pennsylvania was solidly Democrat from the 1800 election until the Civil War, with Philly being a Federalist/Whig stronghold and part of Andrew Jackson's campaign against the BOTUS was due to it being headquartered there and keeping the city a nagging center of Federalist influence in the state. It was one of a few states Hoover carried in 1932 as Philadelphia mayor Harry Mackey got out just enough votes in the city to tip the state Republican.

PA was generally a swing state from the 1930s to 80s until it became Democrat-dominated in the 90s-2000s but is returning to a swing state since Trump.

posts.com:
This seems like an unexplored mystery to me. It doesn't make any sense, let's address possible explanations.

>The climate is not preservative

While true, there are ruins in literal jungles in Central America and asia.

>The people's were too primitive to make stone structure.

Native Americans were allegedly asiatic and asiatic ppls from all over the globe created complex societies that left stone ruins. I guess one could make the argument that they inherited semi-nomadic traits from thier Siberian ancestors, however Siberians not only domesticated horses, but built thier nomadic lifestyles around horsemanship, while native Americans wiped out north American horses.

>The population density never reached the critical level necessary for complex societies.

This is a very real possibility due to the fact that it has so much habitable land, even then, populations would have likely coalesced around rivers for fresh water, but not too far from the ocean for easy access to salt, essentially the regions that hold the majority of the modern eastern seaboard population.

Those are the obvious go to explanations for the mysterious lack of ancient ruins, but imo, none are really sound so I present the following possibility:

>They were destroyed by religiously zealous Christian settlers in an act of historically hidden iconoclastic destruction.

It's not unusual for ancient works to be destroyed by religious fundamentalists viewing them as heathenistic idolatry, it even happens to this very day, see ISIL. Thus I believe the true explanation to the mystery could lie in religious fundamentalism of the early European settlers. Monoliths, temples and religious sites could have likely been destroyed without a trace then modern American cities built overtop of where they once stood.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14631981
It's the Appalachian mountain range. Just South of the entryway into the Appalachians (~Talking Rock, GA) there are tons of large Mississippian mounds. Some pretty great mounds in Florida, Alabama, etc. But generally the bigger monuments are correlated with flat areas and rivers like the Mississippi.

Also, one thing to keep in mind is that most of their structures were either wood or earthen, both of which erode faster than their mesoamerican counterparts. Especially faster in the climates of the Appalachians and Gulf coast.

The last thing I will say is that when you read the accounts of the natives found by the early Spanish expeditions in the area, it seems that there was a mass die-off of culture/civilization fairly recently. Tribes are very separated, living really grueling unhealthy lives, were very poor, and occupying lands/structures that they weren't native to.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14640423
Most Romans lived in crowded tenement buildings called insulae, made of mud or cheap timber, and were prone to collapsing or burning down. These buildings had basically zero amenities even by Roman standards. The upper crust had luxurious private homes called domus with many rooms and private courtyards, sometimes even indoor plumbing depending on how rich they owner was. If a domus was in poor repair, they renovated it. If an insulus was in poor repair, they tore it down and built a new one in a couple days, often cannibalizing material from the old building to save on costs.

Most Americans live closer on the spectrum toward the domus than the insulae, due to the standard of living for the average person increasing so much over the last 2000 years.

posts.com:
As the 1876 election season began, some of the crooks who plagued the Grant Administration were pushing him to run for a third term, calling for "four more years of good stealings." But in December 1875, Congress passed a stern resolution reminding the president of the two term tradition. At the RNC in Cincinnati in June, party bosses ended up nominating Ohio governor Rutherford Hayes as a compromise candidate. Charles F. Adams remarked dourly that "Hayes is a third-rate nonentity whose only positive qualities are that he offends no one." As a former Civil War colonel, Hayes appealed to veterans, and he had a reputation for spotless honesty. He also hailed from a key swing state.

The Democrat convention was held in St. Louis and nominated New York governor Samuel Tilden, who had gained a reputation as a corruption-fighter and the man who bagged "Boss" Tweed. The party platform called for combating Republican corruption and an end to Reconstruction.

When the Electoral College met in early December, there was trouble brewing. Tilden had gotten 50% of the popular vote to Hayes's 47%, but Hayes had exactly one more electoral vote (185 to 184) and there were irregularities in Florida, Louisiana, and South Carolina where paramilitary groups such as the Red Shirts were engaged in widespread intimidation of black voters. Both parties sent election commissioners to the disputed states and as the weeks passed, a major political crisis was imminent.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Constitution stipulates that the vice president, in his role as president of the Senate, shall, in front of Congress, open the electoral votes and Congress was to count them. But who exactly? On this point the Constitution didn't clarify whether the House or Senate would do the counting, and the 44th Congress was a divided one with a Democrat House and Republican Senate. Whichever one got to count the votes would simply choose their respective candidate.

Democrats began yelling "Tilden or blood!" and militia started to arm themselves. President Grant ordered Army units to Washington DC to police the capital in case violence broke out. Trying to avert disaster, Congress passed the Electoral Count Act in January. This specified a commission of 15 men, seven Senators, seven Representatives, and one Supreme Court Justice. The votes were counted in February, and when Florida's disputed ones came out, they were referred to the commission, which ruled 8-7 to give the state's electoral votes to Hayes.

Infuriated Congressional Democrats vowed to filibuster until the heavens fell in, but behind closed doors a compromise was being arranged. Democrat leaders bit their tongues and agreed to accept Hayes as president in exchange for removal of the last remaining occupying troops in the South. This settlement was made on March 1, 1877, with three days left to Inauguration Day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Also disputed were Oregon's electoral votes, as one of the electors was found to be a currently serving postmaster and thus ineligible to be an elector. The Democrat governor of the state threw his vote out and substituted a Democrat elector, but the electoral commission ultimately awarded all three of the state's votes to Hayes.

Colorado participated in its first presidential election and was also the source of controversy as the state had been admitted to the union only three months before Election Day and had not had time to set up a proper election system. The Republican-controlled state legislature voted rather than election by popular vote, giving the new state's three electoral votes to Hayes. This was the last time in a presidential election that a state legislature selected electors rather than selection through popular vote.

>The Gilded Age was one of close elections and considerable voter enthusiasm--turnout often topped 70%. The Republican Party had taken advantage of the Civil War and the absence of Southern Democrats from Washington to thoroughly entrench its machine across the Northern states and for a quarter century ran on having saved the nation from disunion and ended slavery--the frequent invocation of war memories in elections came to be known as "waving the bloody shirt." Republicans had as a voter base much of the rural and small town Midwest and Northeast, and the support of the large body of Union army veterans--the fraternal veterans' organization known as the Grand Army of the Republic was also widely dubbed "Generally All Republicans." Democrats, still somewhat in disrepute from the war, depended on the South and immigrant laborers in the Northern industrial cities. Differences between the two parties were not huge and party loyalty was often more regional and ethnic-driven than ideological. The GOP nominally still stood as the supporters of black civil rights but those became gradually less relevant as Reconstruction faded.

>Overall the Gilded Age was a time when few outstanding men gravitated to politics and it seemed that America's best and brightest found their way into the world of big business instead. The days of great statesmen like Thomas Jefferson, Henry Clay, and Andrew Jackson were long gone and most Gilded Age politicians seemed like ants by comparison.

posts.com: How did the Ottomans react to the discovery ofthe new world? Are there any written records?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14640125
After a few decades they ended up reopening the Silk Road, around 1520 or 1530, but by then they were finished. The oceanic routes rented much more, Spanish merchants bought spices, silk and porcelain from the Philippines; Portuguese and Dutch from their bases in Indonesia and India.
The route was also already finished, since the beginning of the 15th century the Iberians had made great efforts to find alternative routes, not closing the route would have given the Turks perhaps 50-60 years useful for European kingdoms without a maritime tradition that would have bought it from the Venetians, Aragonese and Genoese.
